economic_context.details: Babillon's late father had forced sale of her garden to pay a debt. She had disputes over payment for vineyard work. She accused Jacquotte Gottatz of stealing linen and goods worth 30 francs. She left her husband partially because he refused to feed her, forcing her to work as day laborer. She and husband had bought house for 600 francs, paid 450 cash, then faubourg burned and husband refused to pay rest, so garden was taken for debt.

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a remarkably detailed trial record with extensive witness testimony and a rare outcome - release. Babillon was a poor, elderly woman who had left an abusive husband and worked as a day laborer. The trial shows complex social tensions including debt disputes, property conflicts, and her defense of a previously accused witch. The Change de Nancy showed unusual restraint, approving only limited torture (thumbscrews) and ultimately releasing her. The defense material is particularly rich, with Babillon giving detailed explanations for all accusations. The trial reveals significant economic hardship and the vulnerability of poor, separated women. Notable that she had reputation of 20 years according to one witness, yet was still released.
